review_title: Excellent benefits don't justify the low wage and high stress.

It's nice to have, and it's more than many other jobs provide, but Starbucks is simultaneously pumping gasoline into the fire and rendering it moot. Make no mistake, this job will break you. Even the prospect of Starbucks paying for all of my transition related surgeries wasn't enough to keep me here. pros:
-Really good benefits even if you're part time (free weekly bag of coffee, Spotify premium, insurance, company stock, etc.)
-The job itself of making coffee and drinks can be really fun
-Depending on your store, you can make lifelong friends and the workplace can be a lot of fun if the stars are aligned.
-Very flexible hours that you can make work for any lifestyle
cons:
-Unreasonable expectations a lot of the time. There are serious issues with hours and labor being cut despite the store being constantly busy with people ordering complicated 6 drink orders at a time and you simply don't have enough people to keep up with that and finish the necessary tasking at the same time
-Often extremely overwhelming. I can walk away from shifts so mentally, physically, and emotionally drained that I don't want to do anything for the rest of the day. It is very hard to "leave work at work"
-Depending on where you work, customers have a tendency to be extremely abusive. They have come to expect that they can lie and scream and yell do anything and not only get away with it, they will come out with handfuls of recovery cards and a store manager bending over backwards to "make the moment right" no matter how poorly the customer might have just treated some 16 year old in their first week of training. In my experience, management very rarely backs me or my coworkers up even when we do everything in our power to placate the customers and they are still irate for no reason.
-You don't get paid nearly enough for all that you are doing. There is no time to relax when you're there and you're expected to be full blast working and sweating and multitasking yet you will see only minimal raises once a year. Sure, you also get Spotify premium but that doesn't pay the bills. Benefits don't substitute for a living wage which Starbucks does NOT pay.
-Extreme amounts of waste. You are required to fill your pastry case to the brim every single day and depending on your store, it might not even be food safe so you never serve out of it and just throw easily $100 worth of food away every single night.
-Policies are very strict.... unless a customer yells and screams enough then it's ok to break them and "make the moment right."
-At least in my store, POC historically do not last long because of the brutal treatment they receive from customers especially compared to Caucasian workers. Then they are not protected by management and it feels very unsupportive

cons: VERY fast-paced. There's a reason they give you free coffee throughout your shifts. Manager was exceptionally rude to all the employees. pros: Incredible team, great boss, flexible hours, and a happy and positive environment. Customer service isn't so bad if you learn how to communicate well with people. Customers generally want to have a good time when they enter an establishment and it's easy to create a welcoming and rewarding environment for you and the customer if you present an open personality.
cons: Customers can also have a negative impact on you. The environment in Starbucks is typically streamlined, efficient, and pleasant. On the downside you can have a total rogue personality walk in the door and bring in negative energy with them. It's like with meeting anyone though, there are a few bad seeds and Starbucks just introduces you to a lot of different people at one time. Having a bad interaction with a customer is inevitable, but it's wise to distance yourself emotionally from the complaint and try to understand where the person is coming from. You never know what someone is going through.

pros: Flexible scheduling, great benefits, performance based incentives. Starbucks attracts a lot of interesting people, have met some of my best friends as customers or coworkers, very positive culture and messaging from upper level leadership all the way down. You control your own destiny.
cons: Can be a lot of work, sometimes overwhelming, if things get away from you can definitely end up being in the store way more than 40 hours a week. A lot of repetitive tasks, can seem a little monotonous at times, but better than most in the QSR industry I would imagine.

review_title: Great place for college students and part-time workers!
pros: There are a lot of career growth opportunities at Starbucks which is great. Especially for younger folks who want to get some leadership experience.
cons: The only downside is that as a full-time job the pay is not enough to cover basic expenses, at least in California. This is to be expected at most minimum wage roles, but even on the management level, the pay is fairly low compared to cost of living.
